_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTERNATIONAL WAXES INCORPORATED (IWI) FARMERS VALLEY, PA PLANT 

The International Waxes, Inc. Farmers Valley plant is a manufacturing facility located in Smethport, McKean County, PA. It is a wholly owned subsidiary of the International Group Incorporated (IGI) of Ontario, Canada. IGI is the largest independent wax refiner and blender in North America, with refineries in Canada and the United States. 



Health, Safety, and Environmental Responsibility 

IWI and it parent body IGI are committed to managing health, safety, and the environment as a core business value. The company integrates health, safety, and environmental management into all aspects of business as a competitive advantage in achieving profitable growth and accelerated productivity. 

The IWI Farmers Valley plant is a wax manufacturing facility that has approximately 135 employees. The plant's products are used to make specialty waxes, including micro-crystalline waxes for the food and beverage industries. 

Due to various regulated substances handled at the IWI Farmers Valley, the plant is subject to 

OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (29 CFR 1910.119(e) and the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule (40 CFR Part 68). 

RMP regulated substances include Anhydrous Ammonia and Propane. The plant's storage and use of these chemicals exceeds the specified thresholds of 10,000 lbs. 

In accordance with the requirements of the RMP Rule, a description of the following six elements are provided for the IWI Farmers Valley plant: 



1)    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

    It is the goal of the IWI Farmers Valley plant to operate a safe and environmentally sound facility by identifying and controlling health, safety, and environmental risks related to its operations by:



a.    Designing, operating, and maintaining its processes to protect people, property and the environment

b.    Conducting and continually reviewing and improving programs for safety, health, and e

nvironmental management

c.    Establishing processes to assure that all laws and regulations applicable to its operations and products are known and observed



The accidental release prevention and emergency response management systems associated specifically with the plant's use on anhydrous Ammonia and Propane involves:

a.    The integration of Safely Management Systems, devices and technologies inherent in the design of the process

b.    Use of Safe Operating Procedures and management practices

c.    Operator training and certification

d.    The ongoing maintenance of plant and equipment

e.    Preparation and testing of site Emergency Response Plan

f.    Maintenance of onsite emergency preparedness, response equipment and a trained Fire Response Team

g.    Coordinating efforts and resources with local emergency response services, and communicating with the community



2)    Description of the Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled

    The IWI Farmers Valley Plant produces fully refined waxes, including food and beverage grade micro-crystalline waxes from various petroleum distillate feed stocks. Feed stocks and products are shipped into and out of the facility via tank trucks and rail cars. The plant has approximately 135 employees and operates 24 hours per day. There are two chemicals at the Farmers Valley plant that are subject to the RMP regulation; anhydrous Ammonia and Propane. 



Anhydrous Ammonia is a toxic colorless gas with a strong pungent odor. Ammonia is used as a refrigerant to cool feedstock to the Methyl-Ethyl-Ketone (MEK) Unit. The normal maximum inventory of Ammonia is approximately 40,000 pounds.



Propane also is a colorless flammable gas at atmospheric temperature and pressure. It has a vapor density of 1.52 (air = 1). Propane is used as a solvent to remove heavy resins from the vacuum tower bottoms in the Propane De-Asphalting (PDA) Unit. The normal maximum inventory of propane is approximately 190,000 pounds.



3)    The General Accidental Release Preve

ntion Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

    The General Accidental Release Prevention Program at the IWI Farmers Valley plant consists of 12 elements. Each of these elements are components of the sites PSM Program summarized below.



a.    Process Safety Information

    Written Process Safety Information (PSI) is maintained for the MEK and PDA Units by the plant's Engineering and Safety Departments. The information compiled includes:

i.    Data on the safe use and handling of Ammonia and Propane (e.g. Safety Data Sheets);

ii.    Data on the process technology (e.g. process flow diagrams, process chemistry, flow rates, storage capacities, operating limits and evaluation of the consequences of deviation);

iii.    Data on the equipment used in the process (e.g. piping and instrument diagrams, materials compatibility, energy ratings and classification, control devices and emergency systems, ventilation systems, and design basis including conformance to applicable codes and standards).

        PSI for the MEK and PDA Units were generated before and during the Process Hazard Analyses for the process that use Ammonia and Propane. This enables the employees involved in operating these processes to identify and understand the potential hazards associated with the process. These PSI also include the following information.

i.    Corrosivity data

ii.    Thermal and chemical stability data

iii.    Ventilation system design data

iv.    Design codes and standards employed

v.    Material and energy balances

vi.    Safety systems



b.    Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs)

Revalidation PHA studies for the processes involving Ammonia and Propane have been completed in accordance with PSM Regulations using the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) technique. Each Process Hazard Analysis addresses aspects including process hazards, process incident history, process control devices, equipment location, and human factors. A team of employees having experience and knowledge of the process design, operation and mainte

nance, and knowledge of how to complete a PHA performs each study. The plant uses OS Suites software's Management of Change (MOC) module to track action item database, and the plant's Management of Change process described below is used to track and document process changes, which occur as a result of recommendations from the Process Hazard Analyses. 



c.    Safe Operating Procedures

    Written operating procedures are prepared for all processes at the facility, including those using Ammonia and Propane. The operating procedures provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities in the plant. Procedures are updated to reflect current operating practices, and are certified annually for accuracy. 

    Specific information and instructions covered by operating procedures include startup, normal operation, emergency operation, shutdown, operating limits, operating controls, chemical-specific health and safety information, required personal protective equipment, and use of safety systems. Written Safety procedures are also provided for specific operations such as Hot Work, Lock-out/ Tag-out, Confined Space Entry and Line Breaking.



d.    Training

    Employees involved in operating processes using Ammonia and Propane have received training to ensure they have the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely carry out the requirements specified in the written Operating Procedures. Refresher training is provided every two years at a minimum, or sooner if warranted by changes to operating conditions, equipment or procedures. If refresher training is required more frequently than every two years, it will be triggered through the Management of Change process (described below). Training records are maintained for each employee to show the date training was conducted, the material covered by the training, and the means used to verify that the training was understood.



e.    Mechanical Integrity

    The IWI Farmers Valley plant has a program to ensure the Mechanical Integr

ity (Ml) of equipment used to process and handle Ammonia and Propane. This includes inspecting, testing and maintaining equipment such as pressurized vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency control devices, pumps and valves. Written procedures have been prepared to define the scope and requirements of the Mechanical Integrity program. Maintenance employees involved in carrying out the Mechanical Integrity program are certified by the Maintenance Manager to complete the required tasks in a safe manner. 

    If deficiencies are noted during equipment inspection and testing, corrective actions are taken in a timely manner to assure the safe operation of the process. In some cases, equipment inspections are driven by permit requirements as well as the Mechanical Integrity program.



f.    Management of Change (MOC)

    A Management of Change form is generated when there is a change (except for replacement in kind) to equipment, process chemicals, technology, procedures, or a change to the facility that will affect a process that handles Ammonia or Propane. Work orders for such changes pass through the Safety Department and Engineering to ensure the proposed change is carefully evaluated before implementation (e.g. to assure that proper materials of construction and good engineering practices are employed). Engineering will make changes to the P&ID's to keep the Process Safety Information up to date. Operations and Maintenance personnel are trained prior to start-up of a modified process.



g.    Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

    Prior to start-up of a new or newly modified process involving Ammonia or Propane, a Pre-Startup Safety review is conducted. The review is to ensure that the equipment and installation meets design specifications, a Process Hazard Analysis has been completed, employee training has been completed, and safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place. 



h.    Compliance Audits 

    Compliance a

udits for processes involving Ammonia and Propane are conducted every three years at a minimum to ensure that the elements of the general accidental release prevention program (forming a part of the site's PSM Program) are up to date and being implemented. Records of the compliance audit reports are maintained to document the results of the audits and any corrective actions taken. 



i.    Incident Investigation 

    All incidents that resulted in or could have resulted in a release of Ammonia and Propane are investigated promptly. The incident investigation starts with the submission of incident information in OS Suites prepared by the supervisor on duty at the time of the incident. The report recommendations are conveyed to the plant Management Team and plant personnel. The Incident Investigation Team is made up of employees having experience and knowledge of the processes affected by the incident, and knowledge of incident investigations. 

    Following the incident investigation, a report is prepared to include the following information:



i.    date, time, and location of the incident

ii.    employee(s) involved in the incident, and their roles

iii.    date of the incident investigation

iv.    names of the employees on the incident investigation team in attendance

v.    description of the incident, including chronology of events

vi.    root causes and contributing causes, including conditions at the time of the incident

vii.    recommendations to prevent recurrence

    

    Follow-up actions that are taken as a result of the recommendations in the incident investigation report are documented and records of the reports and follow-up actions are maintained for a minimum of 5 years.



j.    Employee Participation

    All employees at the IWI Farmers Valley plant have the opportunity to access and participate in the sharing of information related to process safety for the processes involving Ammonia and Propane. Employees in the maintenance and operating areas attend monthly safety meetings t

o learn about new or modified processes and discuss specific safety topics. Employees routinely have opportunities to participate in other safety processes in the accident prevention program. These include Process Hazard Analyses, Management of Change, Employee Training, and Incident Investigation. At each monthly Joint Safety & Health Council meeting, consisting of Management and Union safety representatives, the group has opportunity to allow for input from employees on any of the 14 PSM elements and corresponding RMP elements.  Descriptions of incidents are shared in Safety Committee Meeting Minutes, and the status of outstanding recommendations from incidents are shared monthly with all employees.



k.    Hot Work Permits

    The IWI Farmers Valley plant has an established Hot Work permit program. Hot Work operations include burning, welding, drilling, grinding, torch cutting or other spark producing activity. Under the program, a hot work permit must be issued prior to commencing hot work operations in the Ammonia and Propane units. The hot work permit indicates the type and method of hot work to be conducted, the equipment that the hot work will be performed on, the date, time, and location authorized for the hot work, the presence of fire prevention and protection systems meeting the requirements of 29 

CFR 1910.252(a), and signatures of the supervisory employees authorizing the hot work. A separate Hot Work permit must be issued for each Hot Work operation, and a separate Hot Work permit must be issued for each day. A copy of the Hot Work permit must be displayed at the job location while hot work is in progress, and the permit is maintained on file after the completion of the Hot Work.



l.    Contractors

    Prior to retaining contractor services (i.e. Maintenance) for work in the Ammonia and Propane units at the IWI Farmers Valley Plant, the contractor safety program and performance are evaluated. This evaluation includes a review of the contractor's OSHA 300 lo

g, injuries and illnesses, safety policies, training, medical monitoring, and review of any applicable site-specific health and safety plan (HASP) prepared by the contractor. The information supplied by the contractor is retained on site while the contractor is engaged in work activities. 

    Prior to commencing work on site, each contractor employee receives a safety orientation by the Safety Department. The safety orientation covers information on the hazards associated with the process areas where the work will be performed, safety procedures and systems to be used, overview of the site emergency response program including specific procedures to be followed in case of an emergency, and a review of site safety rules and applicable operating procedures. A record of each contractor employee's sign-off on the safety orientation is maintained on file at the site, including the date the training was completed. Once the safety orientation is complete, the contractor is responsible to ensure that each contractor employee performs the assigned work in a manner consistent with the information provided during the safety orientation. If the contractor assigns new employees to the job after work has commenced, the contractor must also ensure that each new employee receives a safety orientation prior to starting work on site. Failure of the contractor or any contractor employee to abide by these requirements is grounds for immediate dismissal from the site. All active contractors receive an annual safety orientation refresher. 



These elements all form components of the site's PSM Program. Further details can be found in the site's PSM Manual.



4)    The Five Year Accident History

    During the past 5 years there have been no accidental releases of Ammonia or Propane for IWI  Farmers Valley Plant, that meet the reporting requirements of the RMP rule.



5)    The Emergency Response Plan

    The IWI Farmers Valley Plant has an Emergency Response Program for the purpose of protecting

employees, contractors, public health and the environment. The program includes a written Emergency response Plan, employee training in emergency response procedures, procedures to review and update the plan, and procedures for the use, inspection, testing, and maintenance of emergency response equipment.

    The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of Ammonia or Propane at the plant. The Emergency response Plan also includes procedures for administering first aid and emergency care. 

    The Emergency Response Plan includes notification procedures for informing the public and outside agencies in case an accidental release occurs. Outside agencies such as fire departments, the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC} and state environmental agencies are notified according to regulatory reporting requirements and as necessary to provide or assist with the emergency response. 

    The Emergency Response Plan is coordinated with the LEPC, and information in the plan is readily available to the local emergency response officials for the purpose of developing and implementing the community emergency response plans. 

    Offsite community response activities are implemented in accordance with the community emergency response plans as developed by the LEPC. Representatives from the IWI Farmers Valley Plant meet regularly with local fire department personnel to review procedures, training requirements, equipment needs, and to conduct training and review site emergency response. 

    The facility Emergency Response Plan has been communicated to the McKean County Emergency Management Agency. Internal training drills and exercises have been conducted. 

Emergency Response Procedures for Ammonia and Propane releases: 

    In the event of a chemical release, the site's Emergency Coordinator or another plant representative will notify the McKean County Emergency Management Agency by call 911 or 814-887-5070. This notification will co

nstitute notification of the LEPC. 



McKean County EMA responsibilities include: 



Immediately notify in order:



a.    McKean County EMA Director (Tracy Carl, Tel: 814-887-5070)

b.    Smethport Fire Department

c.    McKean County Commissioners

d.    Priority Care Ambulance Service

e.    Surrounding County EMAs, (if necessary)

f.    PA State Police

g.    Port Allegany Fire Department (Mutual Aid)

h.    Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency (PEMA)



The site's Emergency Coordinator responsibilities include but are not limited to: 



Upon determining that an emergency situation exists at the facility they shall:



a.    Issue initial report to LEPC through the McKean County EMA 

b.    Provide additional information as available to LEPC

c.    Complete any other notifications as required

d.    Meet emergency response units at the staging area and assist in establishing a Command Post

e.    Provide additional information or recommendations to Emergency Response Agencies

f.    Generally coordinate on-site response to the incident, including ensuring on-site personnel are safe and accounted for.



Further specific details are provided in the site's Emergency Response Plan. 



Emergency Management Agency responsibilities include but are not limited to: 



The actions taken by EMA will depend largely on the scope of the situation. The EMA Director will:



a.    Determine situation (Communicate with FEC)

b.    Activate EAS as warranted

c.    Activate EOC as warranted

d.    Appoint On-Scene Coordinator

e.    Warn hospitals if necessary

f.    Activate Mass care centers, as needed

g.    Notify County Commissioners, PEMA, Keating Township Supervisors, Keating Township EMC, Eldred Township Supervisors and EMC, PADEP and PA Fish Commission



Specific details can be found in the Offsite Emergency response Plan for the IWI Farmers Valley Plant developed and maintained by the McKean County LEPC. 



    Priority Care Ambulance Service responsibilities include but are not limited to:



a.    Immediate response to the s

taging area

b.    Coordinate with on-scene EMA Officers, fire department officers, and On-Site Coordinator participate in establishment of the Command Post and have a designee remain to coordinate communications and activities

c.    Coordinate with medical command physicians and hospital officials and notify receiving hospitals of situation

d.    Assist with establishment of a decontamination zone

e.    Once patient contact can be made, establish a triage area and treat victims accordingly

f.    Coordinate the transportation of sick and injured with hospital(s)



Pennsylvania State Police responsibilities include but not limited to: 



Pennsylvania State Police will perform all police functions as required, with assistance of surrounding municipal police departments and the McKean County Sheriff's Department. They shall:



a.    Control access to restricted areas

b.    Coordinate manning of designated access control points and traffic control points

c.    Dispatch vehicles to alert residents



Community Protective Actions: 



The decision to relocate, shelter-in-place, or evacuate residents is solely that of the County 

Commissioners. Detailed procedures for these actions are contained in the McKean County EOC. Criteria to be reviewed for evacuation and/ or sheltering:



a.    Quantity of release

b.    Additional risk from the facility

c.    Rate of the release

d.    Duration of the release

e.    Chemical released

f.    Meteorological condition-wind direction and speed



More details on the facility Emergency Response Plan may be accessed through the McKean 

County LEPC.



6)    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

    Further actions will focus on further reducing the risk of releasing Ammonia or Propane and are to include:



a.    Changes to plant operating procedures

b.    Improvements to plant instrumentation and control

c.    Install additional explosion proof control rooms
